quotedStatus.name: Andrew D. Huberman, Ph.D.
quotedStatus.text: The most dangerous thought in life is “if only…” Nothing that follows those words comes true. Embrace reality. Think. Pick a course of action & execute. The amount of time & energy people waste wishing things & others were different instead of leaning into their agency is sad.

quotedStatus.name: Katherine Boyle
quotedStatus.text:
Technology and the Family

Thank you so much, Tony, for that kind introduction. It’s a pleasure to be here today at the American Enterprise Institute to speak about the opportunity in front of us to rethink technology’s relationship to the family. When I say relationship, many of us think of the screens we hold in our hands or the amount of time our toddlers spend watching Cocomelon. And those are all important debates. Today, I want to discuss a deeper, philosophical alliance between technology and the institution of the family.

We recently watched the Vice President head to France where he discussed the importance of American dominance in artificial intelligence, and I’ve been struck by the new administration’s focus on innovation. Those of us listening to the inaugural address just last month couldn’t help but notice references to colonizing Mars, the split atom, holding all the world’s knowledge in the palm of our hands. It’s refreshing to see technology celebrated as the engine of American economic growth after years of Washington denigrating it. And we’re now finally seeing enthusiasm for how government can leverage our technology sector to promote American Dynamism by unleashing limitless energy, deterring conflict, and manufacturing abundance of all kinds.

And indeed, investing in American Dynamism my day job, my life’s work and my calling. But today, I want to talk about my other job. My most consequential job according to the Ordo Amoris, a job that is deeply tied to building American Dynamism in the most concrete way. And that is my job and my duty as Mother. For all the talk of Technology and the State, there should be much more talk about that other institution that is perpetually at war with it.

The Institution of the Family.

All of history is a war between the family and the state. Any college student studying Plato’s Republic learns quickly of this conflict, though it’s often only discussed in political theory classes. But in practice, it’s clear these two institutions are often incompatible in their quest for control over how we live, what we believe, what we worship, our history and our daily reality. If this sounds a bit hyperbolic because the family now seeminglysits comfortably inside the state, that is because the state has been winning this civilizational war against the family for decades.

The long 20th Century should teach us this. It is a story of American growth and excellence, but it can also be accurately told as a story of the weakening of the family. It begins with thefundamental transformation of industry, where mothers and fathers are pulled from the home to work in factories, then companies. It proceeds with two atrocious world wars in Europe, where millions of families are decimated. The strength of states is greatly intertwined with war—states grow stronger in war while families are literally destroyed. It’s no coincidence that as we look to our European neighbors, we now see a continent subsumed with regulation, censorship, green authoritarianism, and a birth rate that predicts their demise.

A very strong state, yes. But very anemic families.

We then move to Communism and the Cold War, where we see Communism’s brutal attack on the family for both political and psychological reasons. The one-child-policy that ravaged China with forced infanticide wasn’t just to remind mothers that the good of society matters more than the good of her home. It was a reminder that the family is not, nor will ever be powerful enough to compete with the Chinese Communist Party.

quotedStatus.name: Brian Armstrong
quotedStatus.text:
Great news!

After years of litigation, millions of your taxpayer dollars spent, and irreparable harm done to the country, we reached an agreement with SEC staff to dismiss their litigation against Coinbase. Once approved by the Commission (which we're told to expect next week) this would be a full dismissal, with $0 in fines paid and zero changes to our business.

This is hugely vindicating, especially because many people questioned my decision to engage in litigation with the SEC on this matter in 2023. People told me the courts would give a lot of leeway to the government. They said public market investors wouldn't like it. They said it would take years and cost us tens of millions of dollars in legal fees (which it did). They said the agency would use mafia tactics like trying to pressure other companies not to work with us while the lawsuit was underway (which they did).

But I knew a few truths that helped make it an easy decision to fight them in court:

1. The SEC was wrong on the law.
They were exceeding the authority given to them by congress by asking us to delist a number of assets that were not securities. We had taken a conservative approach to ensure we weren't listing any securities, and the SEC itself had allowed us to go public in 2021 after reviewing our listing standards in depth. We tried to “come in and register” but it turned out it was a fake offer, as every crypto company discovered. Regulators are supposed to enforce the law, but they can't make up new laws on the spot if they don't like the current ones, or weaponize a lack of clarity in the law.

2. Caving to their demands could have killed the crypto industry in America.
The SEC made it clear to us that the only way to avoid litigation was to delist the many assets they falsely claimed were securities. It was a bullying tactic, pure and simple, driven by Gensler's own political agenda. And if we had caved, it would have dramatically limited the scope of which crypto assets were allowed in the US, and pushed the industry further offshore, into the shadows. Never forget how close a few activists in government came to unlawfully killing an entire industry in America! It could have easily gone the other way. Thank goodness the founding fathers created the judicial branch, as a check and balance on executive power.

3. It was the right thing to do for our customers and the industry.
At the end of the day, it didn't matter what our chance of success was. I had to stand up for our customers’ and our industry’s rights. I also knew it would serve as a deterrent for future bad actors around the world we may have to engage with, for them to know that we won't be bullied or pressured. We are comfortable engaging in litigation across multiple fronts, indefinitely, while continuing to build. This is business as usual. As Bain in The Dark Knight says, "you merely adopted the dark; I was born in it".

Growing up I had a naive view that regulators exist to hold companies accountable. What I realized in this ordeal is sometimes, companies must hold regulators accountable who are painting outside the bounds of the law, to preserve freedom. Accountability can actually happen both ways. At Coinbase, our mission is to increase economic freedom, and I initially thought we could achieve this solely through our crypto products. But I'm increasingly realizing that we can move the needle on economic freedom in the courts and through our policy efforts as well, when we see bad actors in government around the world. We plan to do more of this.

I have to give credit here to the Trump administration, for winning the election, and for the departure of  the activist head of the SEC, Gary Gensler, who orchestrated this unlawful action along with Elizabeth Warren, and a handful of their lackeys in congress. I feel confident we would have won this case in the courts either way, given our facts were so strong, but it certainly helped accelerate the process and drive accountability. I called out the sketchy behavior of the SEC back in 2021, and I believe this comment turned out to be prescient.

I want to give a shout out to all the other crypto companies who fought back with their own lawsuits (we certainly were not the only ones).

I want to give a shout out to all the crypto startups who couldn't afford the legal fees, and went bankrupt due to the administration's abusive tactics. Your company may have died, but crypto lives on. Don't stop building.

I want to give a shout out to both Democrat and Republican members of congress, who are working hard to ensure America leads on crypto. I know that Gary Gensler and Elizabeth Warren do not represent the entire Democratic party.

And I want to give a shout out to all the crypto holders in the US who elected pro-crypto candidates, on both sides of the aisle, to make sure your rights were preserved. It turns out the crypto voter is real, and showed up in the millions.

Finally, I expect we'll continue working productively with the SEC on any number of items over the years, just as we do with every agency around the world where we operate. I look forward to the SEC being reformed under Paul Atkins, Mark Uyeda, Hester Peirce, and DOGE, and new more sensible personnel coming into leadership roles. I commend the new leadership that is already in place for working to right this wrong - it's a great step in the right direction, and took courage. Now let's get some crypto legislation passed in the US to finally clarify the rules, and really kick off this next phase of building.

quotedStatus.name: Marc Andreessen 🇺🇸
quotedStatus.text: As America, we now have two choices: win in AI, including win in open source AI. Or let China win in AI, all over the world. I believe it is critically important that we win. Kneecapping American AI, and American open source AI, to protect Big Proprietary AI is asking to lose.

quotedStatus.text: The reality is the secrets are out. Everyone knows how to code a transformer, how to RLHF, how to use reinforcement learning for reasoning. There will be thousands of open source implementations in addition to DeepSeek and Llama. There is no putting this back in the box.

quotedStatus.name: Marc Andreessen 🇺🇸
quotedStatus.text:
Let’s examine this step by step:
https://t.co/n4ipDE06tq Framework Overview
Under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, it is unlawful for employers to discriminate against individuals based on race, color, religion, sex, or national origin. This protection applies regardless of an applicant’s or employee’s citizenship status, provided the individual is lawfully present and has authorization to work in the United States.
2.Application to Chinese Citizens on Visas
Chinese citizens in the U.S. on a visa—whether it’s an H-1B, L-1, or any other work-authorized visa—are legally present and, importantly, have work authorization. Title VII’s protections extend to these individuals. This means that if an employer refuses to hire a Chinese citizen solely because of their national origin, that employer would be in violation of federal law.
https://t.co/dUbwWjtG2K Precedent and Enforcement
Courts and the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) have consistently held that discrimination based on national origin applies to all legally authorized workers. The law does not distinguish between citizens and noncitizens when it comes to protection from discrimination in employment, as long as the noncitizen is legally permitted to work.
4.Clarification on Work Authorization
The key factor is that the individual must have legal work authorization. If a Chinese citizen is in the U.S. on a visa that does not allow employment (for example, a tourist visa), then the legal context changes because the individual isn’t eligible for employment to begin with. However, for any Chinese citizen on a visa with work authorization, the protections are fully applicable.
5.Conclusion
Yes, I am sure that these anti-discrimination protections apply to Chinese citizens who are in the U.S. on a visa with proper work authorization. Employers cannot legally decide not to hire someone solely based on their national origin, regardless of their citizenship status, as long as the person is legally authorized to work.

This legal framework is firmly established, and employers who violate it can face significant legal repercussions through enforcement by the EEOC or through private litigation.

quotedStatus.name: Yuchen Jin
quotedStatus.text:
judging an engineer by age is BS

- Linus Torvalds wrote Linux at 21
- Steve Wozniak built Apple I at 25
- Palmer Luckey created Oculus VR at 20
- Vitalik Buterin designed Ethereum at 19
- Mark Zuckerberg coded Facebook at 19

Looking back, I realize that 18-25 is the peak time.

"The young do not know enough to be prudent, and therefore they attempt the impossible – and achieve it, generation after generation."

judging an engineer by age is BS

- Linus Torvalds wrote Linux at 21
- Steve Wozniak built Apple I at 25
- Palmer Luckey created Oculus VR at 20
- Vitalik Buterin designed Ethereum at 19
- Mark Zuckerberg coded Facebook at 19

Looking back, I realize that 18-25 is the peak time.

"The young do not know enough to be prudent, and therefore they attempt the impossible – and achieve it, generation after generation."

quotedStatus.name: MAZE
quotedStatus.text:
I just stumbled on a ProPublica site with a tool built in that allows you to see the money wasted by USAID and DoD on failed projects in Afghanistan (up until 2015) and then see what it could have funded in America.

USAID spent $335 million on a diesel fueled power plant that just sat there because Afghans can't afford to import diesel. $300-500 million on a dam that was deemed too unsafe to use. $250 million on a partial road that deteriorated. Millions on healthcare facilities that don't exist. $70 million on contractor fees for projects that were canceled before being started, but they got to keep the money anyway. That sounds nice.

A contractor built a $500k police training facility that melted when it rained because it was made from sand. Really.

The DoD paid almost $500 million for 22 cargo planes that were unsafe to fly and were sold as scraps for about $30k total.

Zero consequences for not delivering. Given more money every year. And this is just Afghanistan to 2015. Imagine the tax dollars being wasted around the world. Sickening stuff.

quotedStatus.name: CEBK CEBK
quotedStatus.text:
More than two thirds of Fortune 500 companies are incorporated in Delaware. Delaware is home to more than 1.8 million corporations, more than the number of residents in the state. In 2023, 80% of all US IPOs were registered in Delaware. More than half of Delaware’s total public revenue comes from this—primarily through levying franchise taxes and seizing unclaimed property (eg all unused gift cards or uncashed checks with unknown owners held by companies headquartered in the state).

Before the 1830s, people often had to receive individualized permission from their legislature to incorporate businesses. Before the 1880s, business corporations were primarily regulated by their charters of incorporation (eg state laws required their private constitutions to include limits on size, purpose, duration, profits, etc). But then our legal system switched into regulating corporate activities rather than corporate charters: each state could pass laws limiting corporate behavior within their borders, regardless of where they were chartered, but they could no longer discriminate against out-of-state charters.

And so every major business began incorporating in the state of… New Jersey! Because it pioneered and led the race to discover desirable incorporation criteria. And then Wilson became governor for two years (1911-1913), and reversed all of these laws aggressively enough to chase all the major corporations to Delaware, where they’ve remained ever since. (Oddly though this is now in many respects the last grand vestige of state sovereignty in corporate regulation, as limits on corporate behavior were seized by the national congress in the 1930s and by the national agencies in the 1970s).

This was also the general period in which pretty much every state merged its “courts of equity” into its “common law courts.” The Anglo legal system had long maintained separate “chancery courts” (which focus more on “fairness” and “management” than strict law, and have way more judicial discretion), but these fell from favor as the common law courts codified their own rules—eg as in the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure—which modernized and standardized and formalized and streamlined the common law system into something much more workable.

And but so Delaware kept its Court of Chancery separate, and gave its judges expansive unilateral powers in corporate affairs to creatively issue injunctions and restraining orders, and to demand specific performance and restitution. The few other states that maintain separate courts of equity basically restrict them to matters like family court. But in Delaware, the governor’s most important power by far is appointing these seven judges to decide—without constraints like juries or law—how “poison pills” work, and which mergers must be blocked, and so much more.

This is of course quite fragile power: if the judges use this leeway irresponsibly, then the majority of Delaware’s revenue, and its only influence on the world, will vanish. And so there were various checks imposed on them, from the typical—all matters of fact would be determined in courts of law, all decisions would be kept within the bounds of law by appellate courts, etc—to the specific (eg the judges must always be split 4-3 between the two major parties).

And now that fragile power is breaking. Their court so clearly abused its power for crazy partisan reasons—especially against Musk—that it can’t be trusted anymore (especially now that we know the president won’t crack down on us for exiting from established prestige monopolies). It was supposed to be mature shadowy power, but so immature performative power captured and puppeted it. Think of it like how the president is supposed to be loud and the agencies are supposed to be quiet, but so during the Delaware presidency this script was flipped: we had an absent vague “president” and screeching politicized “experts.”

All of this is, in my view, good. I’d like to see more courts operate like the Court of Chancery, precisely because this allows for more competition between them (unless they outlaw competition). The problem in my view isn’t that the administrative agencies have acted with increasing discretion—in fact, that’s their one saving grace—but rather that they’ve insulated themselves from competition, as if they’re still just following the rules that nobody can ever be allowed to defect from.

The time of Romance—of agency, leadership, discretion, difference, individuality, brilliance, passion, etc—is returning precisely because the Romance of our old elites has been so clearly shriveling. The very failure of this freewheeling-and-yet-elite body is the herald of true freewheeling elitism. We were almost stuck with boring kludgy infrastructure cargo cults (eg worshipping the 11 powerless child-sovereigns of the S&P500) but now there can be sturm und drang again, and the creativity and selection that goes along with that.

quotedStatus.name: Gappy (Giuseppe Paleologo)
quotedStatus.text:
I just received "Superagency" by Reid Hoffman, and from the first pages it is obvious that it's going to be a forgettable book about The Current Thing. No depth whatsoever.  Does anyone remember "The Road Ahead" or "Business @ the speed of thought" by Bill Gates? Nope. Why? Because Hoffman and Gates are simply intellectual tourists in their respective subjects (AI and The Internets). Which makes me think about two books that have stood the test of time. "Information Rules" by Varian and Shapiro, and "Out of Control" by Kelly. Why are these books still so good? Because the authors, even if they were (kind of) referring to their present, they were in fact writing about subjects they had thought about their entire life. This is also the reason why "Zero to one" by Thiel is still relevant. 

What's the point here? Don't know...
1. the world of good books is sparse.
2. good writers don't improvise. They train for a long time;
3. read only books that are at least 30 year old?

As a further thought, or validation: the only lasting book that Michael Lewis has written is "Liar's Poker". He'd been an minor insider for three years; it was not The Current Thing; and it's kind of old.

In the short run, you can safely skip Hoffman's book and the flood of books on AI, including the inevitable future Michael Lewis book on the subject.

quotedStatus.name: Pascal-Emmanuel Gobry
quotedStatus.text:
It’s February 1st, so I can report. 

I did Dry January. 

And it’s a total crock of shit. 

For context, I usually drink wine and/or cocktails 2-3 times a week. From Jan 1 to Jan 31 I stopped cold turkey and haven’t had a drop of alcohol. 

None, zero, of the alleged benefits materialized. I didn’t get better sleep. I didn’t get more energy. I didn’t feel better in any noticeable way. 

Absolutely no positive change in my life except I no longer got to enjoy a fun activity. 

Total ripoff. 

American Protestant Puritan horseshit.

For context, I usually drink wine and/or cocktails 2-3 times a week. From Jan 1 to Jan 31 I stopped cold turkey and haven’t had a drop of alcohol.

None, zero, of the alleged benefits materialized. I didn’t get better sleep. I didn’t get more energy. I didn’t feel better in any noticeable way.

Absolutely no positive change in my life except I no longer got to enjoy a fun activity.

Total ripoff.

American Protestant Puritan horseshit.

quotedStatus.name: Balaji
quotedStatus.text:
To explain:

Virginia’s time ended long ago, and today it’s just another US state, but it was originally the home of the masculine, noble, and brave Cavaliers.

Massachusetts’ time is now ending, but for almost 400 years it was a center of higher learning. That’s why Harvard and MIT are there.

These were the two most important American colonies. In a sense they compete and cooperate every 100 years.

In the mid 1600s they fought back in England itself. First the Cavaliers vamoosed for Virginia, then the Roundheads migrated to Massachusetts.

Roughly speaking: the Cavaliers were the right and the Roundheads were the left, and the English Civil War was over the same themes of hierarchy vs equality.

In the 1700s they worked together to beat Britain and found the United States.

In the 1800s their descendants fought in the American Civil War.

In the 1900s they worked together again to win WW2 and found the American Empire.

Now in the 2000s they are fighting once again, over the same themes of hierarchy (red) vs equality (blue), even if the geographic center of red has been displaced somewhat to the South and the geographic center of blue has been dispersed across the Northeast.

Others have written about this as well — see the Fourth Turning, Turchin, Yarvin, Walter Russell Mead, Albion’s Seed, and Scott Alexander’s review. See links in next reply.

My view is that red and blue will unfortunately smash each other to pieces over the next several years, and then gray will have to pick up the pieces.

Gray is tech in its modern incarnation of the techbro.

Tech is the intellectual successor to Massachusetts, as the migration to the Internet of Harvard’s best proves. Bill Gates, Zuck, and @paulg all moved away from Harvard in the literal sense. And of course Larry Page, Steve Jobs, Vitalik, and many other college dropouts moved away from Harvard in the metonymic sense.

But in its more recent techbro incarnation, tech is also becoming the virile successor to Virginia. Elon, Zuck, and Palmer Luckey are examples of techbros respectively becoming leaders of men, packing on muscle, and getting serious about the military.

Amazingly, this synthesis — the techbro — did not exist years ago. But it was memed into reality by blue attacks. And has the balance that blue and red both lack. Train weights, yes, but also lift weights.

I think this synthesis, the techbro, will be crucial to what follows. After all, the techbro founded America. Let’s see what they found next.

quotedStatus.name: Tim Urban
quotedStatus.text:
Reading about DeepSeek this week, I can't help but think about the story of Mesopotamia.

The Hilly Flanks above ancient Mesopotamia had rich soil and ample rainfall, so the people who lived there never had to innovate to survive. The less fortunate people living in the dry river valley below the hills had it harder, which by necessity led them to develop irrigation and other clever survival hacks—and it was these people, not those living in the Hilly Flanks, who developed the first cities, the first money, the first writing, and the first civilization...

quotedStatus.name: Mike Coté
quotedStatus.text:
Okay, I feel qualified to opine on this because my field of study is basically the Long 19th Century. And I disagree with the periodization here.

The 20th century was, if anything, short. It ran from 1914 to 1991, ending with the fall of the USSR. And that means the 21st century started in 1991, which makes sense to me, as the fall of Soviet communism ushered in a new era of geopolitical affairs. It also coincides with the rise of China as an accepted world power & the technologization of global society, both of which will come to define the 21st century.

That's my two cents, at least.

quotedStatus.name: Chris Bakke
quotedStatus.text:

quotedStatus.name: Gustavo Petro
quotedStatus.text:
Trump, a mi no me gusta mucho viajar a los EEUU, es un poco aburridor, pero confieso que hay cosas meritorias, me gusta ir a los barrios negros de Washington, allí ví una lucha entera en la capital de los EEUU entre negros y latinos con barricadas, que me pareció una pendejada, porque deberían unirse.

Confieso que me gusta Walt Withman y Paul Simon y Noam Chomsky y Miller

Confieso que Sacco y Vanzetti, que tienen mi sangre, en la historia de los EEUU, son memorables y les sigo. Los asesinaron por lideres obreros con la silla eléctrica, los fascistas qué están dentro de EEUU como dentro de mi país

No me gusta su petroleo, Trump, va a acabar con la especie humana por la codicia. Quizás algún día, junto a un trago de Whisky qué acepto, a pesar de mi  gastritis, podamos hablar francamente de esto, pero es difícil porque usted me considera una raza inferior y no lo soy, ni ningún colombiano.

Así que si conoce alguien terco, ese soy yo, punto. Puede con su fuerza económica y su soberbia intentar dar un golpe de estado como hicieron con Allende. Pero yo muero en mi ley, resistí la tortura y lo resisto a usted. No quiero esclavistas al lado de Colombia, ya tuvimos muchos y nos liberamos. Lo que quiero al lado de Colombia, son amantes de la libertad. Si usted  no puede acompañarme yo voy a otros lados. Colombía es el corazón del mundo y usted no lo entendió, esta es la  tierra de las mariposas amarillas, de la belleza de Remedios, pero tambien de los coroneles Aurelianos Buendía, de los cuales soy uno de ellos, quizás el último

Me matarás, pero sobreviviré en mi pueblo que es antes del tuyo, en  las Américas. Somos pueblos de los vientos, las montañas, del mar Caribe y de la libertad

A usted no le gusta nuestra libertad, vale. Yo no estrecho mi mano con esclavistas blancos. Estrecho  las manos de los blancos libertarios herederos de Lincoln y de los muchachos campesinos negros y blancos de los EEUU,  ante cuyas tumbas llore y recé en un campo de batalla, al que llegue, después de caminar montañas de la toscana italiana y  después de salvarme del covid.

Ellos son EEUU y ante ellos me arrodillo, ante más nadie. 

Túmbeme presidente y le responderán las Américas y la humanidad.

Colombia ahora deja de mirar el norte, mira al mundo, nuestra sangre viene de la  sangre del califato de Córdoba, la civilización en ese entonces, de los latinos romanos del mediterraneo, la civilización de ese entonces, que fundaron la república, la democracia en Atenas; nuestra sangre tiene los resistentes negros convertidos en esclavos por ustedes. En Colombia está el primer territorio libre de América, antes de Washington, de toda la América, allí me cobijo en sus cantos africanos.

Mi tierra es de orfebrería existente en época de los faraones egipcios, y de los primeros artistas del mundo en Chiribiquete.

No nos dominarás nunca. Se opone el guerrero que cabalgaba  nuestras tierras, gritando libertad y que se llama Bolívar

Nuestros pueblos son algo temerosos, algo tímidos, son ingenuos y amables, amantes, pero sabrán ganar el canal de Panamá, que ustedes nos quitaron con violencia. Doscientos héroes de toda latinoamerica yacen en Bocas del Toro, actual Panamá, antes Colombia, que ustedes asesinaron.

Yo levanto una bandera y como dijera Gaitán, así quede solo, seguirá enarbolada con la dignidad latinoamericana que es la dignidad de América, que su bisabuelo no conoció, y el mio sí,  señor presidente inmigrante en los  EEUU,

Su bloqueo no me asusta; porque Colombia además de ser el país de la belleza, es el corazón del mundo. Se que ama la belleza como yo, no la irrespete y le brindará su dulzura.

COLOMBIA A PARTiR DE HOY SE ABRE A TODO EL MUNDO, CON LOS BRAZOS ABIERTOS, SOMOS CONSTRUCTORES DE LIBERTAD, VIDA Y HUMANIDAD.

Me informan que usted pone a nuestro fruto del trabajo humano 50% de arancel para entrar a EEUU, yo hago lo mismo.

Que nuestra gente siembre maíz que se descubrió en Colombia y alimente al mundo

name: Marc Andreessen 🇺🇸
text: Managerialism predates 1945 and ~started with Wilson, but yes, I think "end of post-1945 consensus" is also true and important.
html: Managerialism predates 1945 and ~started with Wilson, but yes, I think "end of post-1945 consensus" is also true and important.

quotedStatus.name: malmesburyman
quotedStatus.text: Periodization of history is notoriously difficult. In the US context, I don’t think you can say anything really started in 1915. The Wilson Presidency was fairly well a continuation, even a moderation, of Roosevelt’s. What I think we are seeing end is the post-1945 consensus.
quotedStatus.html: Periodization of history is notoriously difficult. In the US context, I don’t think you can say anything really started in 1915. The Wilson Presidency was fairly well a continuation, even a moderation, of Roosevelt’s. What I think we are seeing end is the post-1945 consensus.

name: Marc Andreessen 🇺🇸
text: My view: Yes, but the unifying theme was managerialism. Systems at scale, run by expert managers credentialed by elite institutions. A method now increasingly exposed as ineffective, corrupt, moribund, stagnant, rotten. Demoralizing and demoralized. Time for change.
html: My view: Yes, but the unifying theme was managerialism. Systems at scale, run by expert managers credentialed by elite institutions. A method now increasingly exposed as ineffective, corrupt, moribund, stagnant, rotten. Demoralizing and demoralized. Time for change.

Here's my 4-hour conversation with Marc Andreessen (@pmarca), where we discuss a positive vision for the future of America, given the many challenges we face. We talk about the state of the tech industry, the heated AI race, immigration, power & corruption in politics, and of course, most importantly, the critical role of humor and memes to the progress of human civilization.

It's here on X in full, and is up everywhere else too. Links in comment.

quotedStatus.name: AnechoicMedia
quotedStatus.text:
The libertarian story about cost disease has always been confused and wrong.

The reason TVs get cheaper while education gets expensive isn't that one is "technological" or "regulated". There are many regulations on consumer products and imported goods, but fundamentally, consumer goods are a commodity that a competitive marketplace can increase supply of without contesting scarce choke points, like high marginal labor, prime real estate, or prestige signaling slots.

The picture of our current economy is that TVs are practically free, but you have to pay a high hourly rate to have a human laborer come to your house and install it for you. This is despite there being basically zero regulations or licensing for home TV installation.

Observe that infinite free education through technology has already practically existed for a couple decades and has had basically no effect on the price of formal schooling. If you are frustrated that college education hasn't gotten as cheap as fiber internet this is because you misunderstand what the product being sold is. Online school and community colleges already exist that are affordable and accept anybody; They also won't give you a credential that gets you a competitive job.

And who is to blame for devaluing these cheaper education credentials? It's not regulators, but private employers whose hiring decision reinforce the signaling value of expensive, selective schools.

The healthcare system, like education, has a way of absorbing increases in purchasing power. Healthcare has more technology than ever, but this increased technology mostly looks like more and better things for people to buy to get the best care possible, rather than labor-saving devices that give you the same services for lower cost. Such miracles are rare in healthcare because the product being sold is mostly labor, not commodity widgets. Unlike TVs, which people only need one or two of and can defer purchasing, consumers have no practical ceiling on how much healthcare services they can consume, and they usually need them urgently. No new technology is likely to change this until they make a robot that can perform a root canal all by itself.

Libertarians don't actually have a coherent story on how technology is going to make the hospital cost curve look like LCD TVs or software. Instead, the main reforms conservatives and libertarians propose are various forms of rationing to reduce service usage, or regressive fiscal changes so they can stop paying to support other people.

quotedStatus.name: Ozmodiar
quotedStatus.text:
Hypothesis:  The woke crack up of culture and institutions that started in ~2013 was driven in significant part by the democratization of good taste that happened in the 2010s.  Bonus: This also explains why hipsters disappeared.

Prior to around 2010, those who considered themselves urban sophisticates defined themselves, and set themselves apart from the general middle and upper middle class, largely by their good tastes in food, drink, music, and films.  Starting in the early 90s this phenomenon was enabled by the concentration of things like craft beer, international cuisines, indie record stores, and boutique art theaters in major cities and college towns and their absence in other parts of the country, and gave rise to the hipster ideal.

However by the 2010s every small city had multiple craft breweries, plenty of tikka masala, and anyone could have instant access to any movie or music with the click of a mouse.  Even getting ahold of an obscure old camera or record could be done with a click.  Therefore sophisticated taste in food, music, films, etc. was no longer an effective cultural separator between someone who lived in Greenpoint or U Street and someone who lived in Tulsa or Jacksonville.  

With the disappearance of this avenue of cultural distinction, urban sophisticates had to turn to something else.  And they turned to politics, centering their identity around adopting extreme beliefs that bourgeois people could or would not.  

This is a variant of the idea of Luxury Beliefs articulated by @robkhenderson, but with a twist that people in question were not attempting to signal their economic class status in an era of mass material abundance but rather flailing to retain their social sub-cultural status in an era of mass cultural abundance.

name: Marc Andreessen 🇺🇸
text:
# The Substack of the Damned, Part III: Toxic Assets
## A One-Act Play

*Setting: A sleek corporate office in Hudson Yards. Glass walls are covered with graphs showing explosive user growth. Multiple screens display real-time engagement metrics and hate-watch analytics. PAUL KRUGMAN and TAYLOR LORENZ sit at opposite ends of a long conference table, both wearing AirPods and actively ignoring each other while speaking to their respective teams on Zoom.*

PAUL: *(into AirPods, increasingly agitated)* ...and that's why I'm saying Elon's latest tweet about AI is EXACTLY what Mussolini would have posted if he'd had Twitter. Did you see how he used that Italian flag emoji? The parallels are undeniable...

TAYLOR: *(also on call)* ...so basically, I had my team do a blockchain analysis proving that he's been secretly DMing with Peter Thiel about bringing Trump back to Twitter...

*(Their BOARD CHAIR appears on the main screen)*

CHAIR: Good morning! Hoping we can do a quick sync on the upcoming IPO...

PAUL & TAYLOR: *(simultaneously)* They can't be in this meeting.

CHAIR: *(sighing)* We've been over this. Your mutual loathing is literally our core product. OnlyEnemies' entire valuation is based on your ability to monetize your hatred.

TAYLOR: *(checking analytics)* Our last fight about whether Paul's conspiracy board linking Elon Musk to the Knights Templar should count as a corporate asset got us 2 million new subscribers.

PAUL: *(scanning multiple monitors showing Elon's tweets)* You don't understand - he just posted a meme using Comic Sans. This is EXACTLY how democracies die! I've been tracking his font choices since 2018, and there's a clear pattern of...

TAYLOR: *(to her phone)* Timestamp 10:47 AM - subject continues his paranoid ravings about Elon Musk despite multiple interventions...

PAUL: *(also to phone)* Day 847 of documenting the Trump-Musk axis. They both tweeted within the same hour. This can't be a coincidence...

CHAIR: Focus, please. The IPO roadshow starts next week. The banks want to make sure you two still genuinely despise each other.

TAYLOR: *(brightening)* Oh, let me show you the PowerPoint I made documenting every time he's interrupted my TikToks to scream "WHAT ABOUT JANUARY 6TH?"...

PAUL: *(interrupting)* Speaking of which, did you see Elon changed his profile picture? The angle of the lighting is IDENTICAL to a photo of Trump from 2019. I've overlaid them in Photoshop and...

TAYLOR: *(to her watch)* Adding to evidence folder: subject continues to derail meetings with his red string conspiracy boards while literally drowning out marginalized voices...

PAUL: *(frantically refreshing Twitter)* OH MY GOD, Trump just posted about electric cars. TAYLOR, ARE YOU SEEING THIS? This is the smoking gun! The smoking Tesla!

*(A JUNIOR PRODUCT MANAGER cautiously enters)*

PM: Um, sorry to interrupt, but our AI sentiment analysis shows we're not hitting our daily antagonism quotas...

TAYLOR: *(perking up)* Oh really? Because I have some thoughts about Paul's recent thread comparing Elon's Neuralink to the Rise of the Third Reich...

PAUL: *(defensive)* That was a carefully researched 147-tweet analysis! And at least I'm not the one who wrote a 12,000-word Medium post about how my Trump anxiety is "literally violence"...

TAYLOR: *(triumphant)* HAH! So you DID read it! I knew you were hate-stalking my Medium!

PAUL: *(checking multiple phones)* I... I was monitoring it for signs of Musk-bot infiltration! For my upcoming book "Everyone I Don't Like is Literally Trump: A Memoir"!

*(Their CHIEF REVENUE OFFICER appears on another screen)*

CRO: Sorry to interrupt, but engagement is spiking. Should we spin this into a premium livestream?

TAYLOR: *(already setting up ring light)* I'm going to need the "Traumatized But Making Content About It" filter...

PAUL: *(adjusting webcam)* Let me just pull up my 900-slide deck on how Elon's use of emoji is coding for fascism...

*(A THERAPIST appears on yet another screen)*

THERAPIST: Just a reminder about your court-mandated monthly joint session...

PAUL: *(jumping up)* Can't make it! Trump just posted something with an exclamation point. This is DEFCON 1!

TAYLOR: *(rolling eyes)* Oh my god, here we go again...

*(Their LEAD INVESTOR appears on the largest screen)*

INVESTOR: Great news! Our AI has analyzed your interaction patterns and projects that at current hatred trajectories, you'll be able to sustain this dynamic for at least 7 more quarters.

TAYLOR: *(horrified)* Seven quarters? With HIM? That's literally...

PAUL: *(interrupting while putting up new pictures on his conspiracy wall)* Did you know that if you take every third letter of Elon's tweets from the past month, it spells out 'covfefe'? The mainstream media won't report this, but...

TAYLOR: *(gasping)* You wouldn't dare post that theory! I'll leak our Slack DMs where you admitted you had a dream about being invited on Joe Rogan!

PAUL: *(panicked)* Those messages were taken out of context! And I'll have you know that my new AI-powered Musk-Trump correlation detector clearly shows...

TAYLOR: *(also standing)* Oh my god, did you just say AI? This is going in my new series "Male Colleagues Who Think They Understand Technology But Actually Just Have Persecution Complexes"!

*(Their STOCK PRICE immediately jumps 20%)*

PAUL: *(not noticing, focused on his phones)* BREAKING: Elon just liked a tweet about space! This is EXACTLY what happened in Germany in 1933...

CHAIR: *(pleased)* Now THAT's what I call shareholder value!

*[Blackout]*

END

quotedStatus.text:
# The Substack of the Damned, Part II: Mutually Assured Cancellation
## A One-Act Play

*Setting: Six months later. A significantly upgraded office in DUMBO with a view of the Manhattan Bridge. The space now features multiple ring lights, a professional podcast studio, and a neon sign reading "SPEAK TRUTH TO POWER" next to a framed printout of their Substack revenue graph. Late evening. PAUL KRUGMAN sits in an Aeron chair, secretly recording on his phone. Enter TAYLOR LORENZ, who pretends not to notice while starting her own recording.*

PAUL: *(muttering into a hidden microphone)* Day 147 of gathering evidence. Subject continues to use Comic Sans in Slack messages despite repeated warnings...

TAYLOR: *(speaking quietly into her Apple Watch)* Content warning: narcissistic abuse. Day 47 of documenting the hostile work environment created by...

*(They notice each other and quickly pretend to be working)*

TAYLOR: *(with forced brightness)* Paul! I didn't expect you here so late. I was just about to record my daily "Why Web3 Is A Front For The Alt-Right" podcast.

PAUL: *(equally fake)* Oh, don't let me stop you! I'm just finishing my analysis of how Substack's font choices are contributing to wealth inequality.

TAYLOR: *(checking subscriber numbers on her phone)* Have you seen today's metrics? The hate-reads alone...

PAUL: *(interrupting)* I know. We're making more than I did at Princeton. *(under his breath)* Though some of us are clearly contributing more value than others...

TAYLOR: *(while posting to Instagram)* Sorry, what was that? I was just posting about how my therapist says I'm making progress with my Times-induced PTSD. It's doing numbers.

PAUL: *(opening an elaborate spreadsheet)* Speaking of numbers, I've been meaning to discuss the revenue split. Given my Nobel Prize...

TAYLOR: *(snapping)* Oh my god, given your Nobel Prize WHAT? Should we rename it "Krugman & The Girl Who Does Social"? Is that what you want?

PAUL: *(defensive)* Well, my pieces on how every single thing that happens in the world is exactly like the Great Depression do drive significant...

TAYLOR: *(laughing coldly)* Your pieces? The only reason anyone under 60 reads us is my TikTok series on "Economists Who Are Literally Gaslighting You."

PAUL: *(reaching for his blood pressure medication)* I'll have you know my Twitter... excuse me, *X* threads on the correlation between MAGA hat sales and the decline of democratic institutions...

TAYLOR: *(typing rapidly)* This is perfect, actually. I'm adding this to my Google doc titled "Instances of Male Colleagues Taking Credit For My Emotional Labor."

PAUL: *(checking his own secret Google doc)* And I'm updating my spreadsheet called "Evidence That My Co-Founder Is Actually A Sleeper Agent For Peter Thiel."

TAYLOR: *(suddenly looking up)* Wait, what did you just say?

PAUL: *(smoothly)* I said I'm updating my research on how real interest rates affect international trade flows.

TAYLOR: *(narrowing her eyes)* You know, it's funny... I got the weirdest email from Joe Rogan's producer yesterday...

PAUL: *(too quickly)* I can neither confirm nor deny any correspondence suggesting you should go on his podcast to discuss cancel culture!

TAYLOR: *(gasping)* I KNEW IT! You're trying to get me cancelled by my own followers! *(pulls out her phone)* Wait until my Discord server hears about this!

PAUL: *(standing dramatically)* Oh yeah? Well, I have evidence that you've been secretly writing under a pseudonym for... *(dramatic pause)* Bari Weiss's Substack!

TAYLOR: *(clutching her jade roller)* You take that back! I would never... I mean, the payment was just a coincidence...

PAUL: *(triumphant)* HAH! I knew it! I've been working with an econometrician to analyze your prose patterns!

TAYLOR: *(pulling out a folder)* Oh really? Then what do you make of THESE? *(slaps down printouts)* DMs showing you've been sharing MIT ECONOMICS LECTURES with your followers!

PAUL: *(recoiling in horror)* How did you... Those were encrypted!

TAYLOR: You think you're the only one who can do research? I have THREE Gen Z interns whose only job is to dig up dirt on you!

PAUL: *(reaching for his laptop)* That's it. I'm publishing my 47,000-word blog post on why you're exactly like the South Sea Bubble!

TAYLOR: *(already livestreaming)* Hey followers! Don't forget to like and subscribe to watch my former colleague literally demonstrating the definition of gaslighting in real time!

*(Enter a VENTURE CAPITALIST in a Patagonia vest)*

VC: Hi there! Sorry to interrupt, but I couldn't help overhearing your mutual antipathy through the premium glass walls. Have you considered taking on investment to scale this dynamic?

PAUL & TAYLOR: *(turning simultaneously)* What do you mean?

VC: Think about it - you could be the Marketplace of Ideas for parasocial hatred! We'll call it "OnlyEnemies."

PAUL: *(thoughtful)* You know, I have been working on a model showing how weaponized antagonism could revolutionize the creator economy...

TAYLOR: *(already updating her bio)* Adding "Co-Founder, OnlyEnemies (Pre-seed, backed by a16z)" to my profiles now!

*(They both turn back to glare at each other)*

PAUL: *(whispering)* This changes nothing.

TAYLOR: *(also whispering)* Obviously. I've already registered OnlyEnemies.eth.

PAUL: *(aghast)* You WHAT?

*[Blackout]*

END

quotedStatus.name: Marc Andreessen 🇺🇸
quotedStatus.text:
# The Substack of the Damned
## A One-Act Play

*Setting: A WeWork office in Brooklyn, sparsely furnished with the requisite millennial workspace accoutrements - hanging plants, a neon sign reading "HUSTLE," and a small recording setup for podcasting. PAUL KRUGMAN, disheveled and wearing an ill-fitting blazer, sits at a standing desk that he's lowered all the way down. He's muttering while typing furiously on his MacBook. Enter TAYLOR LORENZ, wearing a Patagonia vest and carrying an iced oat milk latte.*

TAYLOR: *(speaking into her phone)* ...and that's why I'm literally being traumatized by the New York Times' toxic work environment. Like and subscribe for part 87 of this TikTok series. *(ends recording)* Oh, Paul! You're early.

PAUL: *(not looking up)* I've been here since 4 AM running regression analyses proving that Elon Musk's Twitter purchase directly caused the rise of global fascism.

TAYLOR: *(sitting down and opening her own laptop)* Omg, perfect. I'm working on a piece about how my former Times colleague Kevin Roose's AI coverage is literally endangering democracy by not being alarmist enough.

PAUL: *(finally looking up, excited)* Did you say endangering democracy? That's my favorite phrase! I've used it 4,827 times in my columns since 2016. Did you know that according to my latest model, democracy is currently being endangered at a rate of 3.7 Reichstags per fiscal quarter?

TAYLOR: *(typing rapidly)* Totally stealing that stat. BTW, I've been meaning to ask - can you proofread my investigation into how Joe Rogan's podcast listeners are secretly coordinating harassment campaigns through Discord servers I definitely didn't make up?

PAUL: *(preening)* Well, as a Nobel laureate...

TAYLOR: *(interrupting)* Oh my god, do you have to mention the Nobel thing every time? At least I'm not living off clout from the 90s.

PAUL: *(defensive)* My trade theory work is still relevant! And I'll have you know my Twitter followers...

TAYLOR: *(savage)* You mean your *X* followers? *(smirks)* God, you're such a boomer.

PAUL: At least I write about real issues like monetary policy and international trade, not whatever TikTok drama you're calling "tech journalism" these days.

TAYLOR: *(standing up)* Excuse me? I'll have you know my deep dive into why that YouTuber's boyfriend's sister's dog groomer is problematic got more engagement than all your economics columns combined!

PAUL: *(also standing)* Oh, engagement! I'm sorry, I forgot that's how we measure truth these days. Tell me, how many death threats have YOU gotten from the Bitcoin community? Because I've gotten...

TAYLOR: *(cutting him off)* Death threats? That's cute. I've had to change my phone number fourteen times because people keep sending me pictures of their lunch with mean comments!

PAUL: *(pacing anxiously)* This is exactly what happened in Weimar Germany, you know. First they come for the economics columnists...

TAYLOR: *(rolling her eyes)* Oh my god, here we go with the historical analogies again. You know what's ACTUALLY like Nazi Germany? When people fact-check my tweets!

PAUL: *(muttering while pulling up Excel)* I can prove statistically that fact-checking is a gateway to authoritarianism... 

TAYLOR: *(looking at her phone)* Great, while you do that, I'm going to doom-scroll through my block list. Did you know I've blocked 43% of all active Twitter users? I'm thinking of writing a memoir about it.

PAUL: *(suddenly looking up)* Wait, what's your take on Modern Monetary Theory?

TAYLOR: *(blank stare)* Is that like... an NFT thing?

PAUL: *(clutching his chest)* Sweet merciful Keynes...

TAYLOR: Whatever. The real question is, why haven't you posted about my latest callout thread? I tagged you like seven times!

PAUL: *(breathing heavily into a paper bag)* I've been busy analyzing how Netflix's password-sharing crackdown is literally the same thing as the Smoot-Hawley tariff...

TAYLOR: *(gasping)* Oh my god, did you just say "crackdown"? That's a traumatic word. I'm going to need to tweet about this.

PAUL: *(throwing papers in the air)* You know what? I'm starting to think the Times was right about you.

TAYLOR: *(deadly serious)* What did you just say?

PAUL: You heard me. You're not a real journalist. You're just... a glorified Reddit moderator with a blue checkmark!

TAYLOR: *(trembling with rage)* Well, at least I'm not an obsolete economist whose entire worldview was debunked by a cryptocurrency my followers told me to buy!

PAUL: *(reaching for his phone)* That's it. I'm calling Dean Baquet.

TAYLOR: *(laughing maniacally)* Go ahead! I've already blocked him! I've blocked everyone! Soon I'll figure out how to block myself!

*Enter a WEWORK COMMUNITY MANAGER*

MANAGER: Excuse me, but we've had noise complaints from the crypto startup next door. They say your arguing is disrupting their morning meditation session.

PAUL & TAYLOR: *(in unison)* CRYPTO?!

*(They both begin typing furiously on their phones, momentarily united in their shared enemy)*

TAYLOR: *(without looking up)* This is going to be an amazing thread...

PAUL: *(also typing)* Already working on a column proving how this is exactly like the fall of Rome...

*[Blackout]*

END

*(They both begin typing furiously on their phones, momentarily united in their shared enemy)*

TAYLOR: *(without looking up)* This is going to be an amazing thread...

PAUL: *(also typing)* Already working on a column proving how this is exactly like the fall of Rome...

*[Blackout]*

END
html:
# The Substack of the Damned
## A One-Act Play

*Setting: A WeWork office in Brooklyn, sparsely furnished with the requisite millennial workspace accoutrements - hanging plants, a neon sign reading "HUSTLE," and a small recording setup for podcasting. PAUL KRUGMAN, disheveled and wearing an ill-fitting blazer, sits at a standing desk that he's lowered all the way down. He's muttering while typing furiously on his MacBook. Enter TAYLOR LORENZ, wearing a Patagonia vest and carrying an iced oat milk latte.*

TAYLOR: *(speaking into her phone)* ...and that's why I'm literally being traumatized by the New York Times' toxic work environment. Like and subscribe for part 87 of this TikTok series. *(ends recording)* Oh, Paul! You're early.

PAUL: *(not looking up)* I've been here since 4 AM running regression analyses proving that Elon Musk's Twitter purchase directly caused the rise of global fascism.

TAYLOR: *(sitting down and opening her own laptop)* Omg, perfect. I'm working on a piece about how my former Times colleague Kevin Roose's AI coverage is literally endangering democracy by not being alarmist enough.

PAUL: *(finally looking up, excited)* Did you say endangering democracy? That's my favorite phrase! I've used it 4,827 times in my columns since 2016. Did you know that according to my latest model, democracy is currently being endangered at a rate of 3.7 Reichstags per fiscal quarter?

TAYLOR: *(typing rapidly)* Totally stealing that stat. BTW, I've been meaning to ask - can you proofread my investigation into how Joe Rogan's podcast listeners are secretly coordinating harassment campaigns through Discord servers I definitely didn't make up?

PAUL: *(preening)* Well, as a Nobel laureate...

TAYLOR: *(interrupting)* Oh my god, do you have to mention the Nobel thing every time? At least I'm not living off clout from the 90s.

PAUL: *(defensive)* My trade theory work is still relevant! And I'll have you know my Twitter followers...

TAYLOR: *(savage)* You mean your *X* followers? *(smirks)* God, you're such a boomer.

PAUL: At least I write about real issues like monetary policy and international trade, not whatever TikTok drama you're calling "tech journalism" these days.

TAYLOR: *(standing up)* Excuse me? I'll have you know my deep dive into why that YouTuber's boyfriend's sister's dog groomer is problematic got more engagement than all your economics columns combined!

PAUL: *(also standing)* Oh, engagement! I'm sorry, I forgot that's how we measure truth these days. Tell me, how many death threats have YOU gotten from the Bitcoin community? Because I've gotten...

TAYLOR: *(cutting him off)* Death threats? That's cute. I've had to change my phone number fourteen times because people keep sending me pictures of their lunch with mean comments!

PAUL: *(pacing anxiously)* This is exactly what happened in Weimar Germany, you know. First they come for the economics columnists...

TAYLOR: *(rolling her eyes)* Oh my god, here we go with the historical analogies again. You know what's ACTUALLY like Nazi Germany? When people fact-check my tweets!

PAUL: *(muttering while pulling up Excel)* I can prove statistically that fact-checking is a gateway to authoritarianism...

TAYLOR: *(looking at her phone)* Great, while you do that, I'm going to doom-scroll through my block list. Did you know I've blocked 43% of all active Twitter users? I'm thinking of writing a memoir about it.

PAUL: *(suddenly looking up)* Wait, what's your take on Modern Monetary Theory?

TAYLOR: *(blank stare)* Is that like... an NFT thing?

PAUL: *(clutching his chest)* Sweet merciful Keynes...

TAYLOR: Whatever. The real question is, why haven't you posted about my latest callout thread? I tagged you like seven times!

PAUL: *(breathing heavily into a paper bag)* I've been busy analyzing how Netflix's password-sharing crackdown is literally the same thing as the Smoot-Hawley tariff...

TAYLOR: *(gasping)* Oh my god, did you just say "crackdown"? That's a traumatic word. I'm going to need to tweet about this.

PAUL: *(throwing papers in the air)* You know what? I'm starting to think the Times was right about you.

TAYLOR: *(deadly serious)* What did you just say?

PAUL: You heard me. You're not a real journalist. You're just... a glorified Reddit moderator with a blue checkmark!

TAYLOR: *(trembling with rage)* Well, at least I'm not an obsolete economist whose entire worldview was debunked by a cryptocurrency my followers told me to buy!

PAUL: *(reaching for his phone)* That's it. I'm calling Dean Baquet.

TAYLOR: *(laughing maniacally)* Go ahead! I've already blocked him! I've blocked everyone! Soon I'll figure out how to block myself!

*Enter a WEWORK COMMUNITY MANAGER*

MANAGER: Excuse me, but we've had noise complaints from the crypto startup next door. They say your arguing is disrupting their morning meditation session.

PAUL & TAYLOR: *(in unison)* CRYPTO?!

*(They both begin typing furiously on their phones, momentarily united in their shared enemy)*

TAYLOR: *(without looking up)* This is going to be an amazing thread...

PAUL: *(also typing)* Already working on a column proving how this is exactly like the fall of Rome...

*[Blackout]*

END

quotedStatus.name: Sebastian Siemiatkowski
quotedStatus.text:
NOTE: Using OpenAi Operator at your bank in EU is illegal by law! Web access for assistants was banned years ago as part of “Open banking”

Here is the story of why:

15 years ago I stumbled into Sofort in Germany. A company with the idea to build a digital assistant that would interact with your banks poor UI, so you as a user could avoid it. Just like operator. Back then it was script based, not AI but it worked. 

I was so impressed Klarna bought the company. It has since then processed billions of dollars. 

But of course banks got scared! What happens if people use the digital assistant only, instead of their bank. And what if the assistant says, stop paying those fees to your bank and let me help you switch?

So German banks sued. They claimed privacy concerns. It went to Brussels and a long lobbying and legal fight pursued. This was the beginning of what we today call open banking!

I and others spent years fighting over consumers right to use digital assistants, when accessing their banks. We knew this was critical to create real competition, in an industry that has been plagued by excess profits for years. 

At first Jonathan Hill from UK was responsible and very supportive. But then he left and a German guy came onboard. He was 100% aligned with incumbent banks and we thought the case was lost. However he did a mistake and let some Russian oligarchs take him for a ride on their private jet. And so he was out. 

Finally @VDombrovskis stepped in. He was smart and supportive but pressure from banks was intense. There was rumors that they were funding privacy groups in Germany, to have them use privacy concerns to kill Open Banking. What if the digital assistant accessed some of your private data?

We were about to loose the vote, when the competitive authorities of EU started getting interested. They suspected the banks were lobbying and pursuing this matter for profit reasons to reduce competition(really…). A few weeks before the vote in parliament they raided the offices of some Dutch and Polish banks. Everyone got super nervous and the Open Banking regulation was passed!

Almost…

A small technical detail was left to EBA (European banking authorities). Should your digital assistant use an API for access to your bank account or the standard web UI you use yourself for accessing your bank?

We pushed as hard as we could. We highlighted and said, if your assistant is mandated to use the API that your bank supplies. What if the API don’t support all the same features. Or the API is broken?

Don’t worry said regulators. You can complain with authorities 😂 

We said at least let the digital assistant, as fall back, use the web UI. Then banks cant cheat, as they will know we can always use the same UI as their human customers. It’s called self regulation. But EBA ignored us. 

Today web UI access for digital assistants as ChatGPT Operator is illegal by law. 

And surprise, surprise the open banking API of European banks, continue to be broken, lack functionality and banks add as much friction as they can. We report and see thousands of issues with these APIs every year. 

And people ask me why open banking has not become a larger success…

What do you say @donaldtusk time for a change? Jest potrzebne!

quotedStatus.name: Marc Andreessen 🇺🇸
quotedStatus.text:
Why AI Won't Cause Unemployment

Marc Andreessen
Reposted Jan 24, 2025

"In retrospect, I wish I had known more about the hazards and difficulties of [running] a business." -- George McGovern

Fears about new technology replacing human labor and causing overall unemployment have raged across industrialized societies for hundreds of years, despite a nearly continual rise in both jobs and wages in capitalist economies. The jobs apocalypse is always right around the corner; just ask the Luddites.

We had two such anti-technology jobs moral panics in the last 20 years — “outsourcing” enabled by the Internet in the 2000’s, and “robots” in the 2010’s. The result was the best national and global economy in human history in pre-COVID 2019, with the most jobs at the highest wages ever.

Now we’re heading into the third such panic of the new century with AI, coupled with a continuous drumbeat of demand for Communist-inspired Universal Basic Income. “This time is different; AI is different,” they say, but is it?

Normally I would make the standard arguments against technologically-driven unemployment — see good summaries by Henry Hazlitt (chapter 7) and Frédéric Bastiat (his metaphor directly relevant to AI). And I will come back and make those arguments soon. But I don’t even think the standand arguments are needed, since another problem will block the progress of AI across most of the economy first.

Which is: AI is already illegal for most of the economy, and will be for virtually all of the economy.

How do I know that? Because technology is already illegal in most of the economy, and that is becoming steadily more true over time.

How do I know that? Because, [see chart].

This chart shows price changes, adjusted for inflation, across a dozen major sectors of the economy.

As you can see, we actually live in two different economies.

The lines in blue are the sectors where technological innovation is allowed to push down prices while increasing quality. The lines in red are the sectors where technological innovation is not permitted to push down prices; in fact, the prices of education, health care, and housing as well as anything provided or controlled by the government are going to the moon, even as those sectors are technologically stagnant.

We are heading into a world where a flat screen TV that covers your entire wall costs $100, and a four year college degree costs $1 million, and nobody has anything even resembling a proposal on how to systemically fix this.

Why? The sectors in red are heavily regulated and controlled and bottlenecked by the government and by those industries themselves. Those industries are monopolies, oligopolies, and cartels, with extensive formal government regulation as well as regulatory capture, price fixing, Soviet style price setting, occupational licensing, and every other barrier to improvement and change you can possibly imagine. Technological innovation in those sectors is virtually forbidden now.

Whereas the sectors in blue are less regulated, technology whips through them, pushing down prices and raising quality every year.

Note the emotional loading of the interplay of production and consumption here. What do we get mad about? With our consumer hat on, we get mad about price increases — the red sectors. With our producer hat on, we get mad about technological disruption — the blue sectors. Well, pick one; as this chart shows, you can’t have your cake and eat it too.

Now think about what happens over time. The prices of regulated, non-technological products rise; the prices of less regulated, technologically-powered products fall. Which eats the economy? The regulated sectors continuously grow as a percentage of GDP; the less regulated sectors shrink. At the limit, 99% of the economy will be the regulated, non-technological sectors, which is precisely where we are headed.

Therefore AI cannot cause overall unemployment to rise, even if the Luddite arguments are right this time. AI is simply already illegal across most of the economy, soon to be virtually all of the economy.

name: Marc Andreessen 🇺🇸
text: I don't think normal people want to live a life of drudgery and servitude any more than creative, motivated, and interesting people do.
html: I don't think normal people want to live a life of drudgery and servitude any more than creative, motivated, and interesting people do.

quotedStatus.name: Jack Donovan
quotedStatus.text:
Creative, motivated, and interesting people have a blind spot when it comes to normal people.

Most people actually need external challenges from work and have no idea what to do without the purpose it gives them. Civilizations rely on them to do the boring stuff.

name: Marc Andreessen 🇺🇸
text: There's no more need for redistribution in the world in which AI drives productivity through the roof and crashes prices of goods and services. That's the point!
html: There's no more need for redistribution in the world in which AI drives productivity through the roof and crashes prices of goods and services. That's the point!

quotedStatus.name: Aleph
quotedStatus.text: @pmarca That’s no chance of people not doing massive redistribution in this world though. Why would they let existing elites take most of the post-singularity surplus when AI can do the jobs elites do as well?
quotedStatus.html: @pmarca That’s no chance of people not doing massive redistribution in this world though. Why would they let existing elites take most of the post-singularity surplus when AI can do the jobs elites do as well?

name: Marc Andreessen 🇺🇸
text: To memorialize, I'm eating a cheeseburger and staying up late.

name: Marc Andreessen 🇺🇸
text: National and global standard of living goes through the roof. People can trivially pay for what they need and spend virtually all their time doing what they want. Creativity, art, science, exploration, entertainment, sports, caring for one another all boom. We never look back.

quotedStatus.name: Marc Andreessen 🇺🇸
quotedStatus.text:
INT. NEW YORK TIMES BUILDING - NEWSROOM - 4AM

The vast newsroom is dark except for the glow of emergency exit signs and the ambient light of the city. Empty desks stretch into darkness. Discarded Kind bar wrappers litter the floor like autumn leaves.

A.G. SULZBERGER sits alone in the dark, illuminated only by his phone's blue light. He stares at the Twitter app, thumb hovering over it, but can't bring himself to tap.

SULZBERGER
(internal monologue)
Four generations. Four generations of Sulzbergers steering this ship, and I'm the one who gets to watch it burn because a billionaire made an ambiguous hand gesture.

(He walks to the window, staring at his reflection)

My great-grandfather covered two World Wars. My grandfather took on the Pentagon Papers. My father stared down presidents.

(bitter laugh)
And I spend my nights wondering if our font choice for headlines could be considered defamatory.

(pacing now)
What would they think of me? Standing here, paralyzed, because we can't figure out if "Area Billionaire Waves At Rally" is too aggressive or not aggressive enough.

(checks phone)
Three thousand more cancellations. Each one with a personalized note about how we've lost our courage. Our spine. Our souls.

(mimicking subscriber voices)
"I've been a loyal reader since 1978, but your silence on Elon's clear embrace of—"

(catching himself)
No, don't even think the word. He probably has a neural link that alerts him whenever anyone thinks it.

(rubs temples)
Remember when journalism was just... journalism? Before every story was a potential extinction-level event? Before billionaires could literally edit reality in real time?

(picks up old newspaper from desk)
"All the news that's fit to print."
(hollow laugh)
Should probably update that to "All the news that won't get us sued into oblivion."

(walks past row of Pulitzers)
Look at you. Mocking me. "Pentagon Papers." Ha. Try publishing classified documents now. The whistleblower would be bought out before the first PDF finished uploading.

(stops at old photo of newsroom)
You had it easy, dad. Your billionaires at least had to wait for their lawyers to wake up before threatening you. Mine just tweet through their morning meditation session.

(pulls out phone again)
Should I check Substack? See how many of our writers jumped ship today?
(puts phone away)
No. That's tomorrow's existential crisis. Today's is still about the gesture. The wave. The... movement-that-shall-not-be-named.

(finds discarded Kind bar, considers it)
Even Rachel's lost it. Yesterday she tried to submit a story connecting Tesla's charging station locations to ancient Roman military outposts. With graphs. Seventeen of them.

(sits at random desk)
David hasn't slept in three days. Just keeps running that clip through different filters. Claims he's found evidence in the fabric displacement of Elon's jacket. Started muttering about "enhanced pixel analysis" and "gestural forensics."

(opens laptop, immediately closes it)
God, remember when our biggest problem was people complaining about the crossword? "Dear Editor, Your Thursday puzzle was unnecessarily cruel." Those were the days.

(standing again, more agitated)
What do they want from us? The subscribers want blood. The lawyers want silence. The board wants profits. The staff wants revolution.

(pacing faster)
Write about him, they cancel. Don't write about him, they cancel. Write about him carefully, he sues. Write about him aggressively, he sues more.

(stops suddenly)
Maybe we should just become a cooking website. "Democracy Dies in Darkness, But These Soufflés Rise in Any Light."

(checks phone again)
Oh God, he's tweeting.
(reads)
"Funny watching old media dinosaurs have midnight crisis meetings. Bet they miss the days when they controlled the narrative. PS: Democracy tastes better with soufflé."

(drops phone)
HOW DOES HE KNOW?

(collapsing into chair)
Four generations. Four generations of Sulzbergers, and I'm the one who has to explain to future journalism students why the Paper of Record became a newsletter about artisanal cheese.

(looking at ceiling)
Sorry, great-grandpa. Turns out the freedom of the press wasn't ended by tyranny or war. Just one man, a social network, and an ambiguous wave that may or may not have been—

(phone buzzes)
No. Don't check it. Don't...
(checks it)
"Area Newspaper Publisher Having Dark Night of Soul - Sources"
Posted one second ago.

(long silence)
I should have gone into dentistry.

The first light of dawn begins to creep into the newsroom. Sulzberger stands, straightens his tie.

SULZBERGER
(out loud to empty room)
Well, time to go explain to the board why we're pivoting to cheese content.

(internal again)
At least Gruyère can't sue us.

He walks toward the elevator. Stops. Looks back at the newsroom.

SULZBERGER
(whispered)
Then again, better check who owns the cheese companies first.

FADE TO BLACK.

END

quotedStatus.name: Marc Andreessen 🇺🇸
quotedStatus.text:
FADE IN:

INT. NEW YORK TIMES NEWSROOM - NIGHT - MOMENTS LATER

Thunder CRASHES again. The door flies open. A.G. SULZBERGER (43, inherited anxiety, bespoke suit) stands in the doorway, his face ashen.

SULZBERGER
The subscribers are revolting.

CAROLINE
(still at desk)
What now?

SULZBERGER
(reading from phone)
"Dear NYT, If you don't cover the Nazi salute I just watched Elon do, I'm canceling my subscription and telling all 43 members of my book club to do the same."
(scrolling)
I have eight hundred more just like it.

RACHEL
(through Kind bar)
We could lose thousands of—

SULZBERGER
(interrupting)
Millions. The Times Square billboard tracker shows we've lost twenty thousand subscribers in the last hour. They're all posting screenshots of their cancellations.

DAVID
(still analyzing footage)
If we slow it down to 1/100th speed, the shadow of his hand clearly forms a—

CAROLINE
David, I swear to God—

MARCUS
(from window)
Remember the last Elon lawsuit? The "African American" headline disaster?

Everyone winces.

RACHEL
(defensive)
Technically, it was accurate...

SULZBERGER
It cost us fourteen million dollars and we had to publish his memes for a week.

Caroline takes another pill.

CAROLINE
What's our legal exposure if we just heavily imply—

LAWYER
(appearing from nowhere)
Devastation. Annihilation. Bankruptcy.
(checking notes)
He's apparently already reserved the entire South District court calendar for the next three years.

RACHEL
(pacing frantically)
But we have an ethical obligation! A moral duty! He's out there, right now, probably plotting to buy democracy itself—

MARCUS
Rachel.

RACHEL
—while his followers mass-produce underground lithium batteries—

MARCUS
Rachel!

RACHEL
—and soon they'll have an army of self-driving Teslas patrolling the streets enforcing mandatory Twitter usage—

DAVID
(looking up from laptop)
She hasn't taken her lunch break yet.

Caroline tosses Rachel a Kind bar. She catches it reflexively, unwraps it with shaking hands.

SULZBERGER
(checking phone again)
Oh God. The Paris Review just published a 12,000-word essay calling us complicit in the rise of techno-fascism for our silence.

CAROLINE
How long ago?

SULZBERGER
Four minutes.

MARCUS
(raising flask)
New record.

DAVID
(still watching clip)
What if we write about the podium instead? I've been studying its edges and there's something suspicious about the—

RACHEL
(through Kind bar)
The way it gleams! Like the golden throne of a—

CAROLINE
NO METAPHORS!

Silence. Rain continues pelting the windows.

SULZBERGER
(quietly)
We've received six hundred requests for comment. From other papers.

MARCUS
(bitter laugh)
Vultures.

CAROLINE
What are they asking?

SULZBERGER
"Why is the Times protecting Elon?"

RACHEL
(shooting up)
We're not protecting him! We HATE him! I have an entire vision board at home dedicated to—

CAROLINE
Rachel!

RACHEL
(smaller)
Sorry. But my vision board...

DAVID
(still transfixed by footage)
If we calculate the angular momentum of his shoulder rotation and correlate it with known examples of—

MARCUS
The last time we mentioned his shoulder movement, he filed in four jurisdictions.

SULZBERGER
(phone buzzing)
The Guardian just posted: "The Paper of Record's Deafening Silence: A Case Study in Modern Media Cowardice."

CAROLINE
(head in hands)
How long?

SULZBERGER
Eight minutes. Three thousand comments already.

RACHEL
(through new Kind bar)
We could write about his hair transplant instead—

LAWYER
(materializing again)
He owns the copyright on all mentions of his hairline.

DAVID
(excited)
But what if we use astronomical measurements to describe the distance between each follicle—

CAROLINE
David, close the laptop.

DAVID
But—

CAROLINE
NOW.

He closes it, hands shaking.

MARCUS
(from window)
You know what's funny? In the time we've been talking, he's probably launched three rockets, bought two companies, and tweeted fourteen times.

RACHEL
(jumping up)
While we sit here, paralyzed by our own—

SULZBERGER
Rachel, that's your sixth Kind bar.

RACHEL
(defiant)
I'm stress-eating my way to the truth!

Suddenly, everyone's phones BUZZ simultaneously.

CAROLINE
(reading)
"Watching the 'paper of record' squirm is better than Netflix. Maybe if they weren't spending so much time in their emergency meeting about my wave, they'd notice Tesla stock just hit a record high."

Stunned silence.

DAVID
(whispering)
How did he know we're meeting?

RACHEL
(paranoid)
He's watching us. He's always watching us.
(looks at Kind bar suspiciously)
What if he bought the Kind bar company?

MARCUS
(checking flask)
Great. Now I need to know who makes this bourbon.

CAROLINE
(standing suddenly)
Okay. New plan. What if we write about his actual words at the rally instead?

Everyone stares at her.

LAWYER
His new terms of service claim he owns all transcriptions of his speech.

SULZBERGER
What about interpretations of his—

LAWYER
Owns those too.

RACHEL
(pacing again)
Analysis of crowd reactions—

LAWYER
Banned by last month's settlement.

DAVID
(reaching for laptop)
The geometric properties of—

EVERYONE
NO!

Caroline pops another pill.

CAROLINE
So we either write nothing and lose half our subscribers...

MARCUS
(from window)
Or write something and lose the whole paper.

SULZBERGER
(checking phone one last time)
Final count: Forty thousand cancellations. Trending hashtag: #NYTEndorsesNazis.

RACHEL
(through tears)
But we hate him so much...

DAVID
(softly)
I have seven spreadsheets at home just tracking his use of irregular verbs...

MARCUS
(raising flask)
To journalism. We barely knew ye.

CAROLINE
(after a long moment)
Run the climate change story.

Everyone looks at her.

CAROLINE
(continuing)
But in paragraph eight, we mention that the average global temperature is rising at approximately the same angle as—

LAWYER
Don't.

CAROLINE
(deflating)

SULZBERGER
